docs.lead_paragraph: MORTALITY IN BALTIMORE IN 1853.--The Annual Report of the Board of Health of the City of Baltimore has just appeared. The total number of deaths in the city during the year 1853, was 5,150; males 2,705, female 2,445, Frge colored persons 673, slaves 135. Among the principal diseases were the following; Applexy, 64; Asthama, o ; Bronchitis, 20; Cholera Infantum.

headline.main: Mayor J. V. C. Smith, M. D., of Boston--His Inaugural.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. SMITH was inaugurated Mayor or boston on Monday. On the occasion he made a good speech. He went in for good salaries to officers, and strict accounts. Public property, he says, is too high in the city. He advises to offer it on good terms to purchasers, taking one per cent, of the purchase money down, and mortgages on the improved properly as security for the balance.

headline.main: How Emilgrant Ships are Managed--The Experience of a Passenger.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Meeting accidentally with a copy of your paper, dated 16th, I noticed an article entitled "Cholera at Sea,"

docs.lead_paragraph: GENTLEMEN--I regret much that my health prevents my uniting with you in this mode of commemorating the birth-day of our illustrious and beloved friend. The commemoration has my warmest approval.

headline.main: THE SAN FRANCISCO.; Letter from Col. Fremont concerning the order of leaving the Ship. The Lucy Thompson. Aid for the Destitute. To the Public. Testimonial to the Sea Captains. Meeting of Merchants, &c. Confirmation of the Statement of the Crew of the Brig Napoleon. The San Francisco--Meeting of Boston Merchants. The San Francisco and the Kilby. Passengers from the Stafferdshire.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Permit me to occupy a space in your paper to correct an error in what seems to be " public opinion," in relation to the order of disembarkation from the wreck of the San Francisco. My office and duties gave me an opportunity of knowing all the facts and circumstances in relation to the transfer of the troops from the steamer to the Kilby.

docs.lead_paragraph: Board of Education. The Board of Education held its regular weekly meeting on Wednesday afternoon--E. C. BENEDICT, Esq, in the Chair. The first business in order was the election of the Committees of the Board. Messrs. Stuart and Fell were appointed tellers. The following was the result:

docs.lead_paragraph: From the returns of the "General Board of Health," as published in the late London papers, we pick out some instructive facts. The cholera has been checked in England, though there has been no day lately in which the disease has not occurred in different parts of the country. In Scotland it still exists with unabated violence.

headline.main: FROM WASHINGTON.; The Nebraska Bill of Senator Douglas. Developments of Sentiment Against it. THE MEXICAN TREATY. Mr. Clayton-Railroad Inventions, &c. THE TREATY WITH MEXICO. MR. CLAYTON. Extracts from Provisions of the Nebraska Bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: The opposition to Senator DOUGLAS' Nebraska bill is gathering strength and consistency every hour. It is so clearly regardless of Northern sentiment, and so bare-faced a bill for Southern votes that it must disgust a large portion even of those who are supposed to be especially benefited by it.

byline.original: SPECIAL CORRESPONDENCE OF N. Y. DAILY TIMES

headline.main: The Maine Law in England--Proclamation of the Times Against it.; From the London Times

docs.lead_paragraph: In a country where everything finds its level, there are not many projects that can be pronounced utterly impracticacle. There is nothing politically impossible in an arbitration clause--nothing, physically, in a railway to Calcutta nor, as far as we know, in an electric cable from Galway to New-York. But there now lies before us the account of a scheme which does seem wholly beyond the range of British possibilities.
